content: The Act titled "Rape Kits and DNA Evidence Backlog Elimination Act of 2003" reauthorizes the DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 (42 U.S.C. 14135(j)) is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for fiscal years 2004-2007 in paragraph (1), and $75,000,000 for fiscal years 2004-2005 in paragraph (2). The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to allocate $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2005, $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2006, and $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2007. Expansion of Combined DNA Index System. The DNA Identification Act of 1994 is amended to include DNA samples from all persons, not just those convicted of crimes, as authorized by jurisdiction laws. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is also amended to specify qualifying federal offenses for DNA analysis. The DNA Identification Act of 1994 is amended to include DNA samples from all persons, not just those convicted of crimes, as authorized by jurisdiction laws. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is also amended to specify qualifying federal offenses for DNA analysis, including felonies, offenses under chapter 109A of title 18, crimes of violence, and attempts or conspiracies to commit these offenses. The Uniform Code of Military Justice is amended to define qualifying military offenses as offenses under the code with penalties including confinement for more than 1 year. The Uniform Code of Military Justice is amended to include offenses with penalties of confinement for more than 1 year. Technical amendments are made to the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 regarding DNA analysis. SEC. 4. FORENSIC LABORATORY GRANTS. The Attorney General can award grants to State or local forensic laboratories to increase the submission of rape evidence kits and biological evidence from crime scenes. Each laboratory must submit a plan by December 31, 2004, to receive a grant. $30,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006 for this purpose. SEC. 5. ELIGIBILITY OF LOCAL GOVERNMENTS OR INDIAN TRIBES TO APPLY FOR AND RECEIVE DNA BACKLOG ELIMINATION GRANTS. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include local governments and Indian tribes as eligible entities to receive grants for DNA backlog elimination. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include local governments and Indian tribes as eligible entities to receive grants for DNA backlog elimination by inserting ``, unit of local government, or Indian tribe'' after ``State'' in various paragraphs and subsections. This is achieved by adding ``, unit of local government, or Indian tribe'' after ``State'' in different sections and subsections. SEC. 6. SAFE PROGRAM. The Attorney General will establish a grant program to award annual grants to SAFE programs that comply with national standards. Programs must submit an application with required information to be eligible for a grant. The Attorney General will prioritize funding for SAFE programs serving underserved populations and will conduct audits to ensure compliance with national standards. Nothing in the Act limits programs from seeking funding from other sources. Authorization of Appropriations: The Department of Justice is authorized to receive $10,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2008 for grants under this section. The funds must be used in compliance with national standards, federal laws, and to ensure overall program effectiveness. SEC. 7. DNA EVIDENCE TRAINING GRANTS. The Attorney General can award grants to train local prosecutors in using DNA evidence. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006. SEC. 8. NO STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS FOR CHILD ABDUCTION AND SEX CRIMES. SEC. 8. NO STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS FOR CHILD ABDUCTION AND SEX CRIMES. This section amends Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, to allow for an indictment or information to be filed at any time without limitation for offenses involving child abduction, sex crimes against minors, and certain felonies. The amendments apply to offenses committed before or after the enactment of this section. SEC. 9. TOLLING OF LIMITATION PERIOD FOR PROSECUTION IN CASES INVOLVING DNA IDENTIFICATION. This section amends Chapter 213 of title 18, United States Code, to extend the statute of limitations for prosecution in cases where DNA evidence implicates a person in a felony until a period equal to the original limitation period has elapsed. SEC. 10. LEGAL ASSISTANCE FOR VICTIMS OF VIOLENCE. Effective Date: The amendments apply to offenses committed before, on, or after the enactment date. Section 1201 of the Violence Against Women Act of 2000 is amended to include dating violence as a form of violence committed in a romantic or intimate relationship. The definition of dating violence considers the length, type, and frequency of interaction in the relationship. Congress believes that funding the Paul Coverdell National Forensic Science Improvement Act is crucial to enhance the quality, timeliness, and credibility of forensic science services for criminal justice purposes.
